metadata.title: Feedback | Apple Developer Documentation
metadata.author: Apple Inc.
metadata.summary: This Apple Developer Documentation page provides comprehensive design guidelines for implementing feedback mechanisms in apps and games across Apple platforms. It covers best practices for communicating status, success/failure states, warnings, and error correction opportunities to users through accessible, context-appropriate methods.
metadata.copyright: Copyright 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

content.text: Feedback
Feedback helps people know what's happening, discover what they can do next, understand the results of actions, and avoid mistakes.

content.description: A stylized illustration showing a hand with index finger pressing or tapping, depicted in a warm orange/peach color gradient. The hand emerges from what appears to be a circular background element. There is a subtle radial glow or feedback indicator emanating from the point of touch, suggesting the concept of haptic or visual feedback from a user interaction. The illustration uses soft, rounded forms and a minimalist design aesthetic consistent with Apple's design language.
content.composition: Centered composition with the hand entering from the left side, finger pointing right toward the center of the circular element
content.mood: Warm, approachable, illustrative of human-device interaction
content.technicalDetails: Vector illustration, likely created for Apple HIG documentation
content.contextualRelevance: This hero image visually represents the concept of feedback - the immediate response a user receives when interacting with a device through touch. The radial glow suggests haptic or visual feedback acknowledging the user's action.

content.text: Providing clear, consistent feedback as people interact with your app or game can make it feel intuitive and encourage deeper exploration. Feedback can communicate several different things, such as:

items.text: The success or failure of an important task or action
A warning about an action that can have negative consequences
An opportunity to correct a mistake or problematic situation

content.text: The most effective feedback tends to match the significance of the information to the way it's delivered. For example, it often works well to display status information in a passive way so that people can view it when they need it. In contrast, a warning about possible data loss needs to interrupt people so they have a chance to avoid the problem.
Best practices

Make sure all feedback is accessible. When you use multiple ways to provide feedback, you reach more people and give them the opportunity to receive the feedback in ways that work for them. For example, when you provide feedback using color, text, sound, and haptics, people can receive it whether they silence their device, look away from the screen, or use VoiceOver. (For guidance on providing haptic feedback, see Playing haptics.)

inlineElements.text: Make sure all feedback is accessible.

content.text: Consider integrating status feedback into your interface. When status feedback is available near the items it describes, people get important information without having to take action or leave their current context. For example, Mail in iOS and iPadOS describes the most recent update and displays the number of unread messages in the toolbar of the mailbox screen, making the information unobtrusive but easy for people to check when they're interested.

inlineElements.text: Consider integrating status feedback into your interface.

content.text: Use alerts to deliver critical -- and ideally actionable -- information. By design, alerts disrupt the current context, so you need to match the importance of the information to the level of interruption. Alerts can lose their impact if you use them too often or to deliver unimportant information. For guidance, see Alerts.

inlineElements.text: Use alerts to deliver critical -- and ideally actionable -- information.

content.text: Warn people when they initiate a task that can cause data loss that's unexpected and irreversible. In contrast, don't warn people when data loss is the expected result of their action. For example, the Finder doesn't warn people every time they throw away a file because deleting the file is the expected result.

inlineElements.text: Warn people when they initiate a task that can cause data loss that's unexpected and irreversible.

content.text: When it makes sense, confirm that a significant action or task has completed. For example, people appreciate getting feedback that confirms a successful Apple Pay transaction. It's generally best to reserve this type of confirmation for activities that are sufficiently important -- because people typically expect their action or task to succeed, they only need to know when it doesn't.

inlineElements.text: When it makes sense, confirm that a significant action or task has completed.

content.text: Show people when a command can't be carried out and help them understand why. For example, if people request directions without specifying a destination, Maps tells them that it can't provide directions to and from the same location.

inlineElements.text: Show people when a command can't be carried out and help them understand why.

content.text: Platform considerations
No additional considerations for iOS, iPadOS, macOS, tvOS, or visionOS.
watchOS

Avoid displaying an indeterminate progress indicator -- such as a loading indicator -- in a watchOS app. An animated indicator can make people think they need to continue paying attention to the display, which isn't a good user experience. To provide a better experience, reassure people that they'll receive a notification when the process completes.

inlineElements.text: Avoid displaying an indeterminate progress indicator -- such as a loading indicator -- in a watchOS app.

Related
Developer documentation

To submit feedback on documentation, visit Feedback Assistant.

pages.pageSummary: This page from Apple's Human Interface Guidelines provides comprehensive guidance on implementing feedback mechanisms in apps and games. It defines feedback as helping users understand what's happening, discover possible actions, understand results, and avoid mistakes. The page outlines best practices including making feedback accessible through multiple modalities (color, text, sound, haptics), integrating status feedback into the interface, using alerts judiciously for critical information, warning about unexpected data loss, confirming significant completed actions, and explaining why commands cannot be carried out. Platform-specific guidance for watchOS advises against indeterminate progress indicators. Resources section links to related topics on audio, haptics, and motion, plus developer documentation and WWDC videos.

sections.title: Feedback
sections.summary: Introduction defining feedback as a mechanism to help users understand app state, available actions, action results, and error avoidance. Lists four types of feedback: status, success/failure, warnings, and error correction opportunities.

sections.title: Best practices
sections.summary: Six key guidelines for implementing feedback: (1) ensure accessibility through multiple modalities, (2) integrate status feedback into UI, (3) use alerts for critical actionable information, (4) warn about unexpected irreversible data loss, (5) confirm completion of significant actions, (6) explain why commands cannot execute.

sections.title: Platform considerations

subsections.title: watchOS
subsections.summary: watchOS-specific guidance to avoid indeterminate progress indicators as they encourage unwanted attention to the display; instead, promise notification upon completion.

sections.summary: Platform-specific feedback guidance. No additional considerations for iOS, iPadOS, macOS, tvOS, or visionOS. watchOS has specific guidance about progress indicators.

sections.title: Resources

subsections.title: Related
subsections.summary: Links to related HIG topics: Playing audio, Playing haptics, Motion

subsections.title: Developer documentation
subsections.summary: Link to UIKit Animation and haptics documentation

subsections.title: Videos
subsections.summary: Two WWDC video references: Designing Fluid Interfaces and Essential Design Principles

sections.summary: Additional resources including related HIG pages, developer documentation, and WWDC video sessions.

semanticStructure.documentFlow: The document follows a standard Apple HIG page structure: title and introduction establishing the topic, followed by best practices with bold lead-in sentences, platform-specific considerations organized by platform, and concluding with resources linking to related content. The page is designed for quick reference with clear section headers and actionable guidance.

keyTerms.definition: Information provided to users that helps them know what's happening, discover what they can do next, understand the results of actions, and avoid mistakes
Passive information display showing the current state of something, ideally integrated near relevant UI items
Interruptive UI elements for delivering critical and ideally actionable information
Tactile feedback provided through device vibration to communicate information
A loading indicator that shows activity without indicating completion percentage, discouraged on watchOS

keyFindings: Effective feedback matches the significance of information to delivery method - passive for status, interruptive for warnings
Accessibility requires multiple feedback modalities: color, text, sound, and haptics
Status feedback should be integrated into the interface near relevant items to avoid context switching
Alerts should be reserved for critical, actionable information to maintain their impact
Only warn about data loss when it's unexpected and irreversible, not when deletion is the intended action
Confirmation feedback should be reserved for sufficiently important completed actions
Error feedback should explain why a command failed and help users understand the issue
watchOS apps should avoid indeterminate progress indicators and instead promise completion notifications

designDecisions.rationale: Ensures accessibility for users who may have silenced devices, look away from screen, or use VoiceOver

designDecisions.decision: Integrate status feedback into interface rather than using separate displays
designDecisions.rationale: Allows users to get information without leaving current context or taking action
Overuse of alerts diminishes their impact and disrupts user flow

designDecisions.decision: Only warn about unexpected data loss
designDecisions.rationale: Users don't need warnings for expected outcomes of their intentional actions

designDecisions.decision: Avoid indeterminate progress indicators on watchOS
designDecisions.rationale: Animated indicators inappropriately suggest users should continue watching the display
